rule: Projects aggregate manure from multiple farms and install a central methane capture system where the baseline lacks methane recovery.
Baseline is the highest-IRR alternative without methane recovery determined through the methodology's IRR/NPV screening steps.
Barrier documentation and CER transfer declarations demonstrate participation and prevent double counting.
Project boundaries cover collection through final sludge treatment with leak-proof infrastructure and consistent fertilizer use.
Emission reductions equal avoided manure methane minus project emissions following the referenced AM tools.
Deduct leakage from pipelines, auxiliary fuel, and offsite residue handling using monitored data or LFAD defaults.
Monitor biogas, methane fraction, and energy consumption continuously and report at least monthly with QA/QC evidence.
Focus DOE inspections on high-emitting farms and reconcile methane balances annually, documenting leak investigations and fixes.

Project restores degraded forest lands and meets additionality tests per Tool 01.
Baseline net GHG removals derived from historical land-use data per Tool 02 guidance.
Project emissions include fossil fuel use, biomass burning, and fertilizer application as per Tool 08.
Leakage from activity shifting and market effects addressed using Tool 14 default factors.
Non-permanence buffer determined via Tool 15 risk analysis and recorded in registry accounts.
Permanent sample plots re-measured at least every five years per Tool 16 QA/QC guidance.
Sampling uncertainty kept below 10% at 90% confidence or conservatively adjusted using Tool 12.
Monitoring reports compile geospatial data, emissions sources, and buffer transactions with full audit trail.
Projects reforest lands without forest cover since 1989 and comply with national forest definitions.
Baseline biomass estimated using IPCC defaults or site-specific sampling following Tool 02.
Net anthropogenic removals equal project removals minus baseline emissions and leakage.
Activity shifting leakage quantified annually using Tool 14 and deducted from net removals.
Non-permanence risks addressed through buffer contributions per Tool 15 guidance.
Field biomass measurements conducted at least every five years using permanent plots.
Sampling uncertainty above 10% addressed with Tool 12 conservative adjustments.
Monitoring reports consolidate maps, inventory data, leakage deductions, and QA/QC evidence.
Small-scale A/R activities eligible when total area < 16,000 ha and participants grouped as defined.
Definitions for grouped smallholder projects include participants, monitoring entity, and leakage belt.
Project boundary includes above- and below-ground biomass, dead wood, litter, and soil carbon pools unless excluded with justification.
Baseline scenario assumes continuation of pre-project land use with carbon stock change set to zero.
Project removals calculated by summing carbon stock changes per pool minus fossil fuel and fertilizer emissions.
Leakage from activity shifting or market effects monitored and deducted using Tool 14 default factors.
Monitoring plan requires permanent plots measured every five years plus tracking of grouped participant compliance.
Data and parameters table specifies default biomass factors and sampling requirements.
Uncertainty calculated per Tool 12; apply deductions when precision exceeds 10%.
Non-permanence risk buffer determined via Tool 15 and updated when risk profile changes.
Normative tools and references (Tools 02, 08, 12, 14, 15, 16) must be accessible to grouped project manager.
Annual net removals computed as sum of pool changes minus leakage and emissions, divided by years between measurements.
Annexes include participant enrollment records, training logs, and dispute resolution evidence.
Wetland restoration projects eligible when activities convert degraded wetlands to forest and meet small-scale thresholds.
Definitions clarify wetland geomorphology, participant aggregation, and leakage belt concepts.
Project boundary includes on-site hydrological interventions and relevant carbon pools except where justified.
Baseline assumes continuation of pre-project wetland degradation with zero additional removals.
Project removals calculated from pool carbon stock changes minus emissions from project operations.
Leakage from displaced wetland uses monitored and deducted using Tool 14 defaults.
Monitoring plan covers hydrology restoration, vegetation plots, and participant reporting.
Data tables specify default biomass factors, hydrological parameters, and monitoring records.
Uncertainty analysis follows Tool 12 with deductions when precision thresholds unmet.
Permanence buffer contributions determined via Tool 15 wetland risk factors.
Normative tools and references maintained for monitoring and verification teams.
Annualized carbon stock change derived from difference in pool carbon divided by measurement interval.
Annexes capture hydrology restoration evidence, training records, and community engagement notes.
